block.p: Dow and S.& P. 500 Gain, But Nasdaq Slumps 2.2% Stocks were mixed as investors switched out of technology companies on fears that their earnings growth might slow and moved into more traditional and cheaper sectors, like consumer products.

The Dow Jones industrial average gained 84.97 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,606.95, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 7.27 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,438.10. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index fell 81.47 points, or 2.2 percent, to 3,685.52. [Page C9.]

P.& G. Meets Lowered Estimates Procter & Gamble, troubled by rising costs, management turmoil and credibility problems on Wall Street, reported fourth-quarter results that were in line with lowered forecasts but said that earnings growth in the first half of its new fiscal year would be sluggish. [C2.]

Ex-Coke Manager Gives Suit Advice A former Coca-Cola benefits manager who has criticized the company's treatment of black workers said that he would urge those workers to retain lawyers to help them determine whether they should accept a settlement reached in June between Coke and four black employees or file their own suits. [C3.]

Three Labels to Sell Music Online In a potentially fundamental change to the way music has been packaged, at least three major record labels -- EMI, Universal and Sony -- plan to begin selling songs over the Internet by the end of the year, enabling users to listen to or download songs for a flat fee. [C5.]

Ad Server Attracts Big Investors Advertising.com, which develops systems that send ads to Web sites to be shown to computer users, is hoping to help accelerate its growth with investments totaling $57 million from sources that include major agency and media companies. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.]

Business Lessons From a Full House ''You can learn a lot about management from managing 18 kids.'' So says Pat Williams, senior vice president of the Orlando Magic. He should know, for he has reared almost enough children for a basketball league of their own. And he has done it despite his demanding professional life, the challenge of keeping such a large family afloat financially and, not least, the decision by his first wife to seek a divorce after 23 years of marriage. The Boss. [C6.]

Softbank Won't Sell Shares in Units Softbank abandoned a plan to sell shares in five subsidiaries, citing potentially costly tax consequences. But there was speculation that Softbank abandoned the plan partly because a spinoff might have made the company less attractive to shareholders. [C4.]

Mixed Signals in Economic Reports The National Association of Purchasing Management said that its factory index was unchanged in July at 51.8, the lowest level since January 1999, but government figures showed consumer spending rose 0.5 percent in June after rising 0.3 percent in May. [C2.]

Sales Offset Payouts on Air Delays Hal Rosenbluth, whose travel management company offered in May to pay cash refunds to customers whose flights were delayed, has paid out more than he expected during this summer of delays and cancellations. But he isn't complaining because ticket sales on the company's Web site are up 40 percent. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. [C8.]
